title: What is the difference between <section> and <div>?
content: Explain when to use <section> semantically versus a generic <div>.
explanation: <section> is a thematic grouping with semantic meaning, often with a heading. <div> is generic and purely for layout.
sampleAnswers: <section> is a thematic grouping with semantic meaning, often with a heading. <div> is generic and purely for layout.

title: Explain the difference between <iframe> and <object> for embedding content.
content: Include considerations for security (sandbox) and responsive layouts.
explanation: <iframe> embeds a separate document, can use sandbox attribute. <object> can embed media with fallback content. <iframe> is preferred for isolated content.
sampleAnswers: <iframe> embeds a separate document, can use sandbox attribute. <object> can embed media with fallback content. <iframe> is preferred for isolated content.

title: What is the difference between <link rel='stylesheet'> and <style>?
explanation: <link> loads external stylesheet, reusable and cached. <style> is inline, used for page-specific CSS, increases HTML size.
sampleAnswers: <link> loads external stylesheet, reusable and cached. <style> is inline, used for page-specific CSS, increases HTML size.

title: How does the element differ from ?
content: Explain responsive image loading with srcset and media queries.
explanation: allows multiple sources with media queries or different formats. only loads one image. Example: .
sampleAnswers: allows multiple sources with media queries or different formats. only loads one image. Example: .

title: Explain the difference between HTML global attributes and element-specific attributes.
explanation: Global attributes like id, class, style, hidden apply to all elements. Element-specific like src (img), href (a), type (input) only apply to certain tags.
sampleAnswers: Global attributes like id, class, style, hidden apply to all elements. Element-specific like src (img), href (a), type (input) only apply to certain tags.

title: What is the purpose of the crossorigin attribute in HTML?
content: Explain how it affects resource fetching and CORS.
explanation: crossorigin controls how a browser handles CORS when fetching resources (e.g., images, scripts). Values: anonymous, use-credentials.
sampleAnswers: crossorigin controls how a browser handles CORS when fetching resources (e.g., images, scripts). Values: anonymous, use-credentials.

title: Explain how the <meter> element works.
content: Provide an example for displaying a task completion percentage.
explanation: <meter min='0' max='100' value='65'>65%</meter> shows progress/completion between min and max.
sampleAnswers: <meter min='0' max='100' value='65'>65%</meter> shows progress/completion between min and max.

title: What is the difference between <progress> and <meter>?
content: Include practical use cases for each.
explanation: <progress> shows task progress towards a goal, e.g., file upload. <meter> shows a measurement in a known range, e.g., disk usage.
sampleAnswers: <progress> shows task progress towards a goal, e.g., file upload. <meter> shows a measurement in a known range, e.g., disk usage.

title: Explain the difference between <noscript> and regular HTML content.
explanation: <noscript> shows content only if JS is disabled. Use for graceful degradation or fallback messaging.
sampleAnswers: <noscript> shows content only if JS is disabled. Use for graceful degradation or fallback messaging.

title: What is the difference between <col> and <colgroup>?
content: How do they help style tables efficiently?
explanation: <colgroup> groups columns in a table. <col> defines styles for individual columns inside <colgroup>.
sampleAnswers: <colgroup> groups columns in a table. <col> defines styles for individual columns inside <colgroup>.

title: Explain how <link rel='preload'> differs from <link rel='prefetch'>.
explanation: preload: fetches critical resources immediately for current page. prefetch: fetches resources likely needed in future navigation.
sampleAnswers: preload: fetches critical resources immediately for current page. prefetch: fetches resources likely needed in future navigation.

title: What is the purpose of the <base> element?
content: How does it affect relative URLs?
explanation: <base href='https://example.com/'> sets base URL for relative links and assets in the page.
sampleAnswers: <base href='https://example.com/'> sets base URL for relative links and assets in the page.

title: Explain the difference between <bdo> and <span>.
content: Provide a use case for <bdo> in bidirectional text.
explanation: <bdo dir='rtl'>Hello</bdo> overrides text direction. <span> has no effect on direction.
sampleAnswers: <bdo dir='rtl'>Hello</bdo> overrides text direction. <span> has no effect on direction.

title: What is the difference between <input type='button'> and <button>?
content: Include default behavior and form submission context.
explanation: <input type='button'> is self-closing, cannot contain HTML. <button> can have HTML content, default type is 'submit' if inside a form.
sampleAnswers: <input type='button'> is self-closing, cannot contain HTML. <button> can have HTML content, default type is 'submit' if inside a form.

title: Explain the difference between <script type='module'> and normal <script>.
content: Include scope, import/export, and execution timing differences.
explanation: <script type='module'> allows import/export, executes in strict mode, scoped to module, defer by default. Normal script runs in global scope immediately unless defer/async.
sampleAnswers: <script type='module'> allows import/export, executes in strict mode, scoped to module, defer by default. Normal script runs in global scope immediately unless defer/async.
